Award.AbstractNarration:
Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory is awarded funding to carry out peer-reviewed NSF scientific sea-going operations on Research Vessel Marcus G. Langseth (Langseth) for CY 2012. In 2012 the R/V Langseth has six science programs planned, encompassing the 195 scheduled operating days. All six NSF science projects will require a seismic capability. One program is a combination of seismic and piston/multi-coring, which will be a first for the Langseth. This is a five-year cooperative agreement, and funding for each year of the agreement will be negotiated and is dependent on the number of days at sea in support of NSF-funded research. R/V Langseth operates as a UNOLS ship, adhering to the UNOLS safety standards and NSF inspections.

Technical Merit
The Langseth provides the U.S. academic community an improved multi-channel seismic (MCS) capability. The ship is able to deploy multiple hydrophone arrays and linear sound source air gun arrays, which improve the quality and reliability of data acquisition. This unique imaging capability enables scientists to tackle a wide range of marine earth science problems. Along with this special capability we are seeking to develop an enhanced general-purpose capacity, which can be used to conduct research in support of various marine science disciplines in locations around the world.
The unique capabilities of the Langseth improve the efficiency, quality and reliability of multichannel seismic data acquisition for the US academic community, enabling the widest range of problems in marine earth sciences to be tackled with substantially improved imaging capability. Although the seismic capability of this vessel is the primary focus for scientific programs investigating the deep earths structure, general oceanographic and marine mammal investigations in little-explored parts of the earth will provide an insight into local and global environmental conditions affecting earths climate and the living resources of the sea.

Broader Impacts
The Langseth, in common with the other ships in the UNOLS Fleet, is more than just an instrument for the collection of scientific data. It is a learning tool, a university educational facility that allows young earth scientists to learn the hands-on aspects of their trade. The 2012 Ship Operations program provides an opportunity to collect new, higher resolution data in unexplored areas, which will add significantly to our understanding of fundamental problems in the earth and ocean sciences, including climate change and natural hazards, such as earthquakes and tsunamis. Outreach efforts include ship tours and community outreach through L-DEO sponsored activities that feature the Langseth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Ship Operations award for the R/V Marcus G. Langseth provides for the  support necessary to carry out assigned oceanographic research projects.  The R/V Langseth is owned by the National Science Foundation (NSF)  and operated by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO) of Columbia University. This ship is a 235-foot global class research vessel that is a specialized seismic imaging facility within the U.S. Academic Research Fleet (ARF) and  provides substantial capability for seismic imaging of the sub seafloor of the worlds oceans. The ship also has the capability to continuously collect other complimentary data sets like gravity, magnetics, wide swath bathymetric seafloor mapping, ocean current profiling, and dissolved carbon dioxide in sea surface waters. The science projects have been supported primarily by NSF but other government agencies like  NOAA and US Geological Survey (Law of the Sea mapping) have supported projects as well along with other US institutions/foundations and international collaborators.

 

Funding under this award specifically covers all vessel related expenses and includes major items like fuel, food, travel, insurance, crew salaries, shoreside support office, ongoing training, maintenance and required shipyards. Vessels within the ARF have to meet a variety of maintenance, safety and behavior standards of the US Coast Guard, American Bureau of Shipping, NSF, and ARF?s own standards to ensure that all crew and scientists that use the vessel can have the best environment possible to complete their projects while at sea.  The Langseth undergoes regular inspections and audits to ensure compliance with all requirements.

 

Over the period of this award from 2012 through June 2018, 26 major projects were accomplished throughout the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and the Mediterranean Sea. 20 of these were for two-dimensional (2D) or three-dimensional (3D) seismic (or acoustic) imaging using  reflection with Multi-Channel Seismic or seismic refraction experiments using Ocean Bottom Seismometers or a combination of both.  Seismic imaging of the subseafloor allows scientists to look in detail at structures, ocean crust, and sediments below the seafloor from a few kilometers to more than 50 km.  The other six projects included supporting sediment coring , Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) deployments, electromagnetic imaging, multibeam mapping and  chemical/biological oceanography.  

 

The R/V Langseth had two shipyard periods supported by this award that included regulatory dry docking and overhauls of major equipment in 2014 and 2016.  The shipyards along with ongoing maintenance and inspection programs have contributed to improved performance and condition of the vessel over the period of this award.   In addition, the main marine seismic system was substantially upgraded via NSF support and equipment donations from industry partners. This has enabled the facility to work with a new generation of equipment and support new marine geology and geophysics proposals from the science community that could not have been done before. For example, the older seismic system had a limit of a 8km towed hydrophone streamer for receiving acoustic reflections while the new system is now over 15km long with over 1200 channels. The improved systems are more reliable and easier to maintain.  Continued evolution of the science systems also has significantly improved  the educational and training aspects of our projects.

 

Training the next generation of earth scientists is a necessary and critical part of our mission in the academic research fleet. Each project often brings new students to sea often for the first time to get hands on experience on how science is conducted in the field.  In addition, annual outreach events at our institution as well as in ports where we visit created important ongoing opportunities to engage people and students in our work. One highlight of such port call events was a visit by President of Chile in January 2017 when R/V Langseth was conducting research on earthquake prone areas along Chilean coast in collaboration with Chilean scientists.
